div.p: TOM JONES.
[Price One Shilling and Six Pence.]
TOM JONES, A COMIC OPERA: As it is Performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL IN COVENT-GARDEN.
By JOSEPH REED.
THE SECOND EDITION.
LONDON, Printed for BECKET and DE HONDT, in the Strand; and RICHARDSON and URQUHART, at the Royal Exchange.
MDCCLXIX.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: IT is needleſs to ſay the following Opera is taken from FIELDING'S celebrated novel of Tom Jones; a production ſo replete with wit, humour, and character, that it can never want admirers while the Engliſh language remains. My extreme veneration for the memory of the truly-witty and ingenious noveliſt, naturally led me to preſerve as much of FIELDING throughout my Opera, as the nature of my plan would allow. Nay, when it was thought neceſſary to ſhorten the piece, leſt it ſhould be too long in repreſentation, I readily parted with my own, to retain as much as poſſible of the invaluable Original.

I have made many material deviations from the novel, both in point of fable, and character. I have ſtripp'd its hero of his libertiniſm, to render him, as I imagined, more amiable and intereſting; and have metamorphos'd Parſon Supple into a country 'ſquire, to avoid giving offence to the cloth. The characters of Weſtern and Honour I have diveſted of their provinciality; leſt the attention of the performers, to the pronunciation of an uncouth and difficult dialect, ſhould produce an Inattention to the more material buſineſs of the drama. I have alſo endeavoured to purge Weſtern's character of its coarſeneſs and indelicacy, in conformity to the refined taſte of the preſent age; and of its Jacobitiſm, from an opinion that ſuch political ſect no longer exiſts, as well as from
a conviction that nothing of party ſhould ever appear within the walls of a theatre.

While I was writing the laſt act of this Opera (which was in June, 1765), the French Tom Jones fell into my hands. I found its plan ſo very confined, and ſo materially different from mine, that I could reap little or no benefit from it. The only particulars, of which I have availed myſelf from Monſ. POINSINET, are the hint of legitimating Jones, and the thought, which gave riſe to my ſecond air. I have quoted the lines, from which I received advantage in the latter inſtance:

q.l: Que les devoirs que tu m'impoſes,

l.hi: Quand ſous tes doigts naiſſent les roſes,
Les epines ſont dans ton coeur.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: N. B. This Opera is entered in the Hall-book of the Company of Stationers; and whoever pirates any part of it will be proſecuted.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.
div.p: Four Country Gentlemen, Servants, Huntſman, &c.
SCENE, during the Firſt and Second Acts, in SOMERSETSHIRE; in the Laſt, at UPTON.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE, A Hall in an old Manſion-Houſe.
div.stage: WESTERN, JONES, SUPPLE, and four Country Gentlemen, juſt returned from a Fox-Chace; two French Horns, a Huntſman bearing a Fox's Head, and a Servant with a large Tankard, which he hands round during the Song.

lg.l: NO ſport to the chace can compare,
So manly the pleaſures it yields;
How ſweet, how refreſhing that air
Inhal'd in the woods and the fields!
As we ruſh in purſuit, new ſcenes ſtill appear,
New landſcapes encounter the eye;
Not Handel's ſweet muſic more pleaſes the ear,
Than that of the hounds in full cry.
New ſtrength from the chace we derive;
Its exerciſe purges the blood:
How happy that mortal muſt live,
Whoſe ſport yields both phyſic and food!
So new and ſo varied its charms, they ne'er cloy
Like thoſe of the bottle and face;
The oftner, the harder, the more we enjoy,
The more we're in love with the chace.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Gentlemen, tho' none of you will ſtay dinner, I muſt inſiſt on your puſhing it about. We've had a hard ride, and a refreſhing draught will not be amiſs—come, brother ſportſman, to our next merry meeting in the field. drinks.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Gen.
sp.p: Thank you, my old ſoul— [taking the tankard.] And here's wiſhing the next fox may give us as much ſport, as that ginger-colour'd gentleman. drinks.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Illo ho! illo ho! hark to him! to him!

sp.speaker: 2d. Gen.
sp.p: Excellent ſtuff i'faith! This will make a man live for ever—I can't part with the tankard without t'other draught— [drinks.] If I were a king, I would make the fellow, that brew'd this ſtingo, my prime miniſter.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Rot thee, Ned, thou'rt a jolly dog, and a true ſportſman!

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Come, here's confuſion to all poachers.

sp.speaker: 3d. Gen.
sp.p: With three chears, gentlemen; with three chears.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Huzza! huzza! huzza!

sp.speaker: 4th Gen.
sp.p: Good b'ye, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Gentlemen all, your moſt obedient. Exeunt the four Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: So my ſiſter and Sophy have din'd?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; madam did not expect you ſo ſoon, and as it was Gazette-day, they din'd at one.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Then let us have dinner immediately. [Exit Ser.] I'll juſt take a peep into the ſtable, to ſee how Chevalier does after his hard chace—didn't he behaved gallantly today, Tom?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Amazingly, ſir!

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: 'Tis one of the beſt pieces of horſe-fleſh that ever was croſs'd. Exeunt—Weſtern ſinging.

div.head: SCENE, a genteel Apartment.
div.stage: SOPHIA working a Chair-bottom, and HONOUR ſewing.

lg.l: When tyrant love, that foe to reſt,
Deſpotic rules a virgin's breaſt,
The needle ſhe employs in vain
To baniſh thought, to baniſh pain:
For while beneath her fingers grows
In mimic bloom the ſilken roſe,
The fair, by real anguiſh torn,
Feels in her heart the growing thorn.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I'm ſorry, ma'am, to ſee you look ſo grave this afternoon. I'm afraid Mr. Jones runs in your head.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Mr. Jones runs in my head! What is Mr. Jones to me?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Nothing, ma'am. He's not a proper match for you to be ſure: with your fortune you may command one of the greateſt lords of the land; therefore you won't certainly ſtoop to marry a beggar and a foundling.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I don't know what you mean by taking theſe liberties with Mr. Jones! The misfortune of his birth is not his crime.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ma'am, if it was a diſgrace, Mr. Jones has a great many people, that carry their heads very high, to keep him in countenance—well, he's one of the ſweeteſt gentlemen that ever trod on ſhoe-leather! Every body likes him: all the neighbourhood, for five miles round, would run through fire and water for him—if I were in your cloaths, and he loved me, as much as I believe he loves you—

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Loves me, Honour! I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ma'am, I may be miſtaken, it's true; becauſe, as the man ſays, we can be ſure of nothing in this world but death and taxes: however I could tell you ſomething, that looks very like it.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Ay! pray what's that, Honour?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He came into the room, as I was ſitting at work, and what ſhould be upon the table but the muff you gave me, and my gentleman whips his hands into it. "La, Mr. Jones, you'll ſpoil it," ſays I; but he ſtill kept his hands in it, and kiſs'd it, and mumbled it, and kiſs'd it—for my part I never ſaw ſuch kiſſes in my life as he gave it.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: When was this?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
Let me ſee—it was the day after I dreamt that I was married to Sir Timothy Tipple—laſt Thurſday—ay it was on Thurſday.—But that is not all neither—yeſterday, as you were playing on the harpſichord, he was in the next room, and look'd melancholly—ſays I, "What's the matter, Mr.
Jones? A penny for your thoughts"—"Huſſy," ſays he, ſtarting up as from a dream, "what can I be thinking of, when that angel your miſtreſs is playing?"—But I'm afraid you're offended, ma'am?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: No, no—proceed.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Then ſqueezing my hand—he ſqueez'd ſo hard, that I thought he would have forc'd the blood out of my finger-ends—"Oh! Mrs. Honour, ſays he, how happy will that man be"—and then he ſigh'd—Upon my faith his breath is as ſweet as a noſegay—but for heaven's ſake, ma'am, don't ſpeak of this; for he gave me a guinea never to mention it. However, as I did not ſwear it, it's only a promiſe, and what ſignifies a promiſe?

lg.l: At court, where true breeding abounds,
They never let promiſes bind 'em:
In country, in cities, in towns,
'Tis likewiſe the mode not to mind 'em.
To promiſes never give truſt,
Of truth they are ſeldom the token;
The old proverb ſays, a pye-cruſt
And a promiſe were made to be broken.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Honour, if you will never mention this affair again, I'll not be angry with you: It may come to my father's ears, and he would be diſpleas'd at Mr. Jones; tho' I really believe he meant no harm.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Harm, ma'am? I'm poſitive ſure he meant no harm—"Yes, Honour, ſays he, I'm neither ſuch a coxcomb, nor ſuch a villian, as to look upon her in any other light, but as my goddeſs; and as ſuch I will always worſhip and adore her while I have breath"—this was all, ma'am; ſo you plainly ſee he meant no harm.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Well, well, let me hear no more of this—I'll take a walk in the garden— [takes up a muff] Lord! what an odious muff is this! I can't bear it—pray fetch me my old one, Honour.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What, that your ladyſhip gave me?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Ay, that; fetch it this minute.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I will, ma'am—the old muff again! Oh ho! aſide, exit.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Love will not be conceal'd. We try to deceive ourſelves, we try to deceive others; but alas! 'tis all in vain. The more we attempt to conceal our affections, the more we expoſe ourſelves; and our very ſervants are witneſſes of our weakneſs.

lg.l: That paſſion, which harrows the ſoul,
By reaſon we ſtrive to remove;
But reaſon's too weak to controul
A paſſion, ſo pow'rful as love.
Then why this vain war with deſire?
Reſiſtance but doubles the ſmart:
The more I oppoſe the fierce fire,
It rages the more in my heart.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Here it is, ma'am. gives it to Sophia.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Thank you, dear Honour—I'll wear it again. Inſtead of it, you may take the luteſtring night town.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ma'am, I'm very much obliged to you— [Exit. Soph. ſighing and kiſſing the muff.] A luteſtring nightgown for an old muff!—to be ſure ſhe does not love Mr. Jones! No, not ſhe, dear creature!—Well if I had twice her fortune, I ſhouldn't think myſelf a crumb too good for him—here he comes! Heavens bleſs him! He's a ſweet man, that's the truth on't!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Mrs. Honour, your ſervant. How does your young lady to-day?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Very well, Mr. Jones—we've juſt been talking of you.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Of me, Mrs. Honour?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—I've been telling her that—that—

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Why what you ſaid, when ſhe was playing on the harpſichord.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Mrs. Honour! How could you, when I ſo earneſtly deſir'd your ſecrecy?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Sir, I had really no deſign to mention it, but Old Scratch puſh'd me on, a purpoſe to make me break my word.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: I ſhall never be able to look her in the face again.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Nay for that matter, you need not be in ſuch a fluſter neither. I don't believe ſhe's angry at you, becauſe ſhe begg'd the muff again, tho' I told her of your kiſſing it.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Again! Why had ſhe given it you?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; and ſhe has juſt now bid me take a ſilk gown for it. Now you know if ſhe was angry, ſhe would ſcarce take to wearing it again.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Why that's true—yet ſhe muſt be diſpleas'd at my preſumption, in entertaining even the moſt diſtant thoughts of her—I pray thee, dear Honour, unſay it all to Sophia: Tell her it was only an invention of thy own. Takes hold of her hand.

sp.speaker: Weſt.
sp.p: Ah! you liquoriſh rogue! what are you about? Honour, go and tell Sophy to come hither.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Yes, ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.l: Come leave off theſe tricks, or
I'll lend you a flick, ſir;
I gueſs you, young dog, what you drive at.
For ſhame! Keep aloof, ſir;
While under my roof, ſir,
Pray none of your wenches in private.
You'll give the world handle
My manſion to ſcandal;
Remember few damſels are barren:
Then beat up elſewhere, ſir,
The game, and forbear, ſir,
To poach any more in my warren.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p:
Kiſs me, Sophy; I have not had a buſs of thee theſe two days.—I want a little of the motion of thy
fingers. [Shakes his fingers.] "Old ſir Simon the king." ſings.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Papa, you have it ſo often, that I wonder you don't tire of it. I have this morning been practiſing an air, which I yeſterday overheard Mr. Jones ſing to ſir Timothy, when you retir'd to take your afternoon's nap—let me give it you: Mr. Jones will perhaps favour you with the words.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Come, Tom, let's have it.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: With all my heart, ſir.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Swains, tell me no more of the tranſports divine
You reap with the women, excluſive of wine.
Wine heightens our pleaſures, each joy will improve,
Adds ſmartneſs to converſe, and fuel to love.
Nor tell me, ye topers, that wine ever made
You perfectly happy without woman's aid.
This maxim attend, if true bliſs you would have,
Of both be a lover, to neither a ſlave.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Thank you, Tom.— [As Sophia plays the ſymphony, the muff drops on the harpſichord.] I wonder what buſineſs your damn'd muff has there to ſpoil your playing?— [throws it away] I wiſh one of my beagles would come, and tear it in pieces!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I would not have it torn in pieces for a thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: O the enchanting angel!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: A thouſand pounds! It was hardly ever worth a thouſand farthings—but I know you ſay this by way of contradiction; you're like your mother for that.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Would I could be like her in every thing! for ſhe was one of the worthieſt women upon earth.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p:
Why there wasn't a worſe wife in all chriſtendom than ſhe made. She would ſit you ſulk, ſulk, ſulking from day's end to day's end, and all only becauſe her father forc'd her to marry me. She had no more affection for me to the hour of her death, than if I had been an Egyptian mummy, or a Ruſſian bear— [Sophia burſts into tears and exit.] Ay, this is always madam's way, when
I talk about her mother—but we muſt crack a bottle together: I didn't drink much above a pint at dinner, and I generally make it up a bottle, by way of concoction, as they call it.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: You know, 'ſquire, I ſeldom object to a propoſal of this kind.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: No, nor to any other propoſal, I'll ſay that for thee.—But what ſay you, Tom?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: No more wine for me I thank you, ſir: I muſt go and change my dreſs.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Dreſs? What ſignifies dreſs, you monkey, when you're among friends?

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd, Jones, if you have not ſome wench or other in your eye, or you'ld hardly take ſo much pains in adorning your perſon.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: So I think, cuz; for what ſignifies dreſs, if one does not want to make the women fond of one?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Very true, ſir; and where is the man that does not wiſh to make the women fond of him?—and ſo your ſervant, gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: I muſt keep a ſharp look-out, or this young rogue will be getting hold of ſome of the huſſies in my family as ſure as a gun.

div.head: AIR. O my kitten.
div.l: And ſhould a young bantling appear,
Dame ſcandal at me will let fly;
Each neighbour will ſnigger and fleer,
"I gueſs who'as a hand in the pye."
The jokers a fine game will go,
And hourly have me on the hip,
With "'ſquire, an old coachman you know
Loves always the ſmack of the whip."

div.stage: Enter Mrs. WESTERN and her MAID.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p:
I think this poſt will never come!—Betty, take that pamphlet, and lay it on my toilette: I muſt finiſh it before I ſleep. [Exit Maid.] This author elucidates the affair of continental connexions in a moſt maſterly manner, and his reaſoning upon the national debt, and
internal and external taxation is unanſwerable—brother, your ſervant. I want to have a little talk with you—nay you need not go, Mr. Supple; it is nothing but what may be mention'd in your preſence.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Well, what is't about, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Pray have not you obſerv'd ſomething very extraordinary in your daughter of late?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Nor you, Mr. Supple?

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Not I, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I am abſolutely aſtoniſh'd at your blindneſs.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Why, is there any thing the matter with the girl?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Yes, I think there is; and of much conſequence too.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: If any thing be the matter, acquaint me with it at once, for you know I love her more than my own ſoul.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Nay, nay, the diſorder is not ſo very dangerous—I believe, gentlemen, you are both pretty well convinced—you more eſpecially, Mr. Supple—that I know the world.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Not one perſon on the whole globe knows it ſo well as yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: That's a damn'd—I know what. aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Nay now, couſin, that is going rather too far. The globe you know is of very extraordinary circumference, and there are undoubtedly perſons on it, ſome few perſons, who perhaps may exceed—at leaſt equal me in that particular—well, I promiſe you I was never more deceiv'd in my life, if my niece be not—

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: What? what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Moſt deſperately in love.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: How? in love? Fall in love without aſking me leave? I'll diſinherit her; I'll turn her out of doors.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: This is ſo like you! Always in a paſſion before you know why.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Zounds! Don't I know—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: You know nothing; nothing in the world: there is ſcarce a leſs intellectual being in the creation—ſuppoſe now ſhe ſhould have fixed upon the very perſon, whom you yourſelf would wiſh? I hope you would not be angry then?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: No, no, no; that makes a wide difference! if ſhe only marries the man I would have her, ſhe may love any body ſhe pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Brother, I muſt compliment you on the increaſe of your underſtanding; for this is poſitively the moſt ſenſible expreſſion that ever eſcaped you—I will diſclaim all knowledge of the world, if the perſon, my niece, hath choſen, be not the very perſon you would chuſe for her.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: But who is he?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Nay, e'en find that out your ſelf. You who are ſo profound a politician—in your own opinion—can be at no great loſs. That judgment, which can penetrate into the cabinets of princes, and diſcern the ſecret ſprings, which move the ſtate-wheels in all the political machines in Europe, can ſurely very eaſily find out what paſſes in the rude, uninform'd mind of a girl.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Siſter, don't talk your court-gibberiſh to me: I don't underſtand the lingo; and moreover, and beſides, you know, I hate every thing that belongs to the court. It's well for thee that thou'rt a woman, or I'd have lent thee many a flick, for talking to me ſo much court-nonſenſe. I'd have thraſh'd thy jacket for thee, I promiſe thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Ay, ay, in that flicking and thraſhing lies all your fancied ſuperiority: Your bodies, not your brains, are ſtronger than ours. 'Tis with you as with the brute creation in general; the greater your bulk and ſtrength, the ſmaller your intellects.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: But prithee tell me what you mean about my daughter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Hold a moment, while I digeſt that ſovereign contempt I have for your ſex—there—now, good politic ſir, with all your prodigious ſhare of ſuppos'd ſagacity, what think you of—Mr. Bliſil?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Blifil! ſpeaking together.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Blifil! ſpeaking together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Ay, Blifil—don't you remember, gentlemen, ſhe fainted away in the field about a month ago, on ſeeing him lie breathleſs on the ground, in conſequence of ſome hoſtilities offer'd him by Jones, on account of a ſarcaſtic ſneer on his illegitimate birth? When we came up to the ſcene of action, did not you obſerve her look pale?

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Yes, as pale as a playhouſe-ghoſt, I perfectly remember.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: 'Fore George, now you mind me on't, I remember it all. I knew Sophy was a good girl, and wouldn't fall in love to make me angry—I was never more rejoic'd in my life, for nothing can lie ſo handy as the two eſtates: they are, as one may ſay, join'd in matrimony already, and it would be a thouſand pities to part them.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: So it would, couſin.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: And yet I can't tell what to think on't; for Allworthy is ſuch a queer chap, that money has no effect on him.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: No effect on him? Then he muſt be made of different materials from the reſt of mankind.

div.head: AIR. Peggy's Mill.
div.l: That gold is an idol all people adore,
Their practice evinces moſt clearly:
E'en patriots themſelves often graſp at this ore,
Their country ſcarce loving ſo dearly.
Let the prelate 'gainſt riches employ tongue and pen,
Be his eloquence ever ſo charming,
Only think of his lordſhip's full coffers, and then—
You'll ſneer at both preacher and ſermon.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: But what would you have me do, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Since you condeſcend to aſk my advice, you may propoſe the match to Allworthy yourſelf. There is no indecorum in the propoſal's coming from a parent. King Alcinous offers, in Pope's Odyſſey, his daughter to Ulyſſes.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: King Alcinous offers Pope Odyſſey his daughter Ulyſſes!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Brother, your ignorance provokes me to ſmile.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Allworthy is gone to viſit a ſick tenant, and will call in his return—ſuppoſe I mention the matter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Do ſo, do ſo; and deſire him to bring Blifil to dine with us to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p:
Odd rabbit it! If Allworthy ſhould refuſe the match, I ſhall be for lending him a flick, as ſure as the
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
devil's in London; for I can't bear to have my girl ſlighted.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Don't be afraid of that; the match is too advantageous to be refus'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Brother, do you ſuppoſe Mr. Allworthy has more contempt for money, becauſe he profeſſes more? You would make a fine plenipo at a general congreſs! You would negotiate with theſe Machiavels, the French, with great dexterity!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: I'm ſure I could make as good a negotiator as you, or any political old woman in the nation; tho' we've a great many of them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: You negotiate? Yes, for a few acres of land, or a ſtack of hay.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Here's a quarrel a-brewing! I had beſt march. Exit.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Before you women ſet up for managing ſtate affairs, you ſhould learn the needful art of keeping a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: I inſiſt on't that we keep ſecrets better than you he-creatures.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: In your intrigues, I grant you; there you've the advantage of us—No, no, ſiſter; tho' the folks at the head of affairs are no great conjurers, yet they are rather wiſer than to truſt an old woman with their ſecrets, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Sir, you're both a brute and a blockhead, and if you had the leaſt ſpice of intellects or good-manners, you would ſcorn to uſe a gentlewoman of my acknowledg'd abilities in this prepoſterous manner.—Notwithſtanding your horſe-laugh, it is my happineſs to be univerſally regarded as a phenomenon in the political hemiſphere, and as a nonpareil in the knowledge of the world—Wiſer than truſt a woman with their ſecrets!—Sir, I beg leave to tell you, there are perſons of the firſt diſtinction—yes, of the very firſt diſtinction in the political world, who have not thought it beneath their dignity to truſt me, ay, me, ſir, with the moſt important ſecrets.—And let me tell you further, ſir, I have had the honour of being cloſetted with a prime-miniſter, and conſulted on an expedition, before it has been communicated to either king or council.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Cloſetted with a prime-miniſter! I'm afraid, ſiſter, there has been ſomething more than politics in the caſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: How dare you have the effrontery to make ſo ſcurrilous and indelicate an innuendo, to a woman of my irreproachable character? A woman, who, inſtead of ſtudying perſonal embelliſhments, hath taken ſo much pains in adorning her head?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you do take pains enough to adorn your head! you build it up to a monſtrous height indeed! Ecod, I can't help laughing, whenever I look at it.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: The women attempted ſome few years ago
Their lovers to charm with a ſmall head;
But now in their noddles as bumpy they ſhow,
As if the whole carcaſe was all head.
This faſhion the ſex of admirers will rob;
Their conqueſts they certainly puſh ill,
In ſtriving to charm with a bolſter'd-out nob,
As large as a Wincheſter-buſhel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Was there ever ſo affronting a ſavage!—Wiſer than truſt a woman with their ſecrets!—He has no more breeding—Were it not for his daughter, I would depart, like an offended ambaſſador, without taking leave.

div.p: Come hither, Sophy—what book is that? Let me ſee it, child—Heloiſa to Abelard!—I thought it was ſomething on love—you bluſh, child!—ah! Sophy, Sophy, I know what paſſes in that little heart of yours, more than you imagine—do you think I don't know the reaſon of your overacting all that friendſhip for Mr. Blifil the other day?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Heavens! Am I diſcovered? (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p:
Nay, you need not bluſh; it is a paſſion, which both I and your father approve—come, conſtitute and appoint me of your privy-council, and I will guaranty to you the peaceable poſſeſſion of your Adonis—don't ſigh, my dear, but out with it all—no reſerve, I conjure you—the
affair is already on the carpet, and your father is going to have a private audience with Mr. Allworthy, in order to propoſe the match, and will invite the heir-preſumptive of your affections to dine with us to-morrow.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: To-morrow, my dear aunt?— [fetching her breath] You frighten me out of my ſenſes!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Oh! my dear, you'll ſoon come to yourſelf, for he's a moſt charming young fellow.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I muſt own I don't know another man, that ſeems to have ſo many good qualities.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he has a great many indeed! I don't wonder at your loving him.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: So brave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: And yet ſo gentle.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: So witty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Yet ſo inoffenſive.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: So humane, ſo ſprightly— ſpeaking both together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: So civil, ſo— ſpeaking both together. My dear, there is no getting in a word with you.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: What ſignifies the circumſtance of his birth, when compared with ſuch qualifications!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: His birth? Pray what circumſtance is there in the leaſt derogatory to the birth of Mr. Blifil?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Mr. Blifil!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Mr. Blifil? Ay, of whom elſe have we had this conference?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Good heaven! Of Mr. Jones I thought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Jones? And is it poſſible you can think of allying yourſelf to illegitimacy? The blood of the Weſterns could never ſubmit to ſuch contamination—you are the firſt; yes, Miſs Weſtern, you are the very firſt of your name, ſince the landing of Julius Caeſar, that ever entertain'd ſo groveling a thought. The female Weſterns have been proverbially call'd the Dianas of the age, ſince the Conqueſt—and you to defile a ſtream of blood, which hath flow'd with ſuch purity for ſo many hundred—centuries!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: My dear aunt, don't put yourſelf in ſo violent a rage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p:
Fall in love with one of ſpurious origin! I thought, miſs, the pride of your family would have reſtrain'd
ſuch monſtrous inclinations.—Love indeed is well enough in trades-people's daughters, chambermaids, and ſuch low-bred reptiles; but in a woman of family it is the moſt ridiculous thing upon earth. To the praiſe of the preſent nobility be it ſpoken, there is hardly any ſuch thing as love to be met with in our right honourable matches.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: But, madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: And you to think of diſgracing yourſelf and family by ſo vulgar, ſo prepoſterous a paſſion!—I'll to your father this inſtant, and inform him of the groſſneſs, the depravity, of your affection.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Alas! my dear madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: It is in vain to importune me; the match is reſolv'd upon, and nothing can, nor ſhall prevent it.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Deareſt aunt, attend my prayer!
Let your indignation ceaſe:
Theſe ſtern looks my boſom tear:
Have ſome pity on a niece!
From this hard, this cruel ſtroke,
Your lov'd darling kindly ſave!
The ſad ſentence, O revoke!
Or you doom me to the grave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: 'Tis all to no purpoſe—your ſolicitation is totally inadmiſſible.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: But, madam, you will ſurely give me time to get the better of my diſinclination to Mr. Blifil?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: It would be fine politics indeed to protract a ſiege, when the enemy's army is at hand, and in danger of relieving the town. As your heart is in ſo critical a ſituation, I will do all I can to haſten the match, and put your honour out of the care of your family—I ſhan't acquaint your father with your hopeful paſſion; but if you ever ſpeak to this ſpurious ſwain any more, he ſhall know the whole. I would therefore adviſe you to evacuate your heart of its attachment to ſo inadequate a pretender as Jones, and turn your thoughts wholly on the intended alliance between you and Mr. Allworthy's heir-apparent. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Bleſs me, ma'am! what makes you look ſo ſad?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Alas! Honour, my father and aunt have reſolv'd on a match between me and Mr. Blifil.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Lord forbid! Even poor as I am, I would ſcarce have him myſelf, for I can't abide him—however, one comfort is, that they can't force you whether you will or no to marry him.—Dear ma'am, do not ſigh ſo.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Yes, I muſt be ſacrific'd to family-views—tormenting thought!

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Thirſt of wealth too oft bewitches
The deluded parent's heart;
But can worldly pomp or riches
Real happineſs impart?
Love's the ſweeteſt, deareſt pleaſure
To the human heart convey'd:
Thoſe, who give up love for treaſure,
Quit the ſubſtance for the ſhade.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I would not tell her that Mr. Jones was in the garden, for fear of offending her—poor ſoul! he's walking by the canal ſtep by ſtep with his arms acroſs, and ſo thoughtful! [walks as deſcrib'd] I'm in a peck of fears and troubles, leſt he ſhould be throwing himſelf in—and yet I think I need not be afraid on't; for hanging and drowning for love is almoſt out of faſhion.—This match with Blifil will be a terrible affair to my poor miſtreſs; for if love has not already got hold of her little heart, I am hugely miſtaken—for my part I can't blame her for liking ſo charming a man as Mr. Jones.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Had I quite clear in land a year
Full twenty thouſand pound,
And did ſurpaſs the faireſt laſs
That ever trod the ground;
Tho' dukes and lords, with ſtars and ſwords,
Should court while courting's good,
For him alone I'd ſlight each don:
I wiſh I may die but I would!
He is in truth a well-made youth,
And of the ſweeteſt mein:
Whoe'er his wife, ſhe'll lead a life
As happy as a queen.
No courtly dame need think it ſhame
To wed, if he ſhould woo.
No ſwain I know could charm me ſo,
I wiſh I may die if I do!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: There can be no hopes of her father's conſent; and Mr. Allworthy would never pardon an attempt to marry her without it—nay I could ſcarce pardon myſelf. Conſcience teaches me, that to repay the friendſhips of hoſpitality by this worſt kind of robbery, is to be the meaneſt, the baſeſt of all robbers.—Yet is there not a great difference between clandeſtinely marrying a friend's daughter from a motive of love, and doing it from a ſordid motive of intereſt?—Certainly—but then her father would diſclaim her; and ſhall I, whoſe ſole ſupport flows from Mr. Allworthy's unmerited bounty, involve her in my diſtreſs? Her, who has been brought up with ſuch tenderneſs, elegance, and delicacy?—That, that hath determined me—No, no, no; let me not make her unhappy, however miſerable I may be myſelf—I muſt think no more of her.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: What pity that nature has caſt
Between us this diſtance in life,
When nearneſs in temper and taſte
Hath form'd us for huſband and wife!
Sould Hymen my paſſion befriend,
How ſweet were each conjugal kiſs!
Such raptures our loves would attend,
That angels might envy my bliſs.

sp.p: Miſs Weſtern, your moſt obedient—this is an unexpected pleaſure indeed!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: The fineneſs of the weather has tempted me out—here's a heavenly afternoon, and the reflexion of the ſun upon the water makes the canal appear remarkably beautiful—I fancy, Mr. Jones, you have ſome little ſhuddering when you ſee that water?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Shuddering, my dear madam! why?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: You cannot have forgot, tho' 'tis ſo long ago, your plunge into the canal, when the bough broke, as you were climbing the tree to recover your little nameſake.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: I aſſure you, madam, the concern, which you felt for the loſs of your bird, will always appear to me the higheſt circumſtance of that boyiſh adventure.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Upon my word, Mr. Jones, your gallantry had very nearly coſt you your life!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Madam, if I have any reaſon to reflect with ſorrow, it is that the water was not a little deeper.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Sure you cannot be in earneſt! This affected contempt of life is only an exceſs of your complaiſance. You would endeavour to leſſen the obligation of having ventur'd it twice on my account—you know it was laſt year in danger, when you broke your arm by leaping off your horſe, to prevent mine from throwing me—you have eſcap'd twice, but beware the third time. Looks at him very languiſhingly.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Oh! Miſs Weſtern, can you deſire me to live? Can you wiſh me ſo ill?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Jones I—I—I don't wiſh you ill: I don't indeed.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Madam, you wiſh me ill, if you wiſh me to live, for life begins to be inſupportable—your caution comes too late; the miſchief is already done.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Nay now I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: My dear Miſs Weſtern, I would not be underſtood—I know not what I ſay—meeting you here ſo unexpectedly, I have been unguarded. I have utter'd that, which I had reſolv'd everlaſtingly to bury in this boſom—pardon me, moſt angelic creature, if I have ſaid any thing to offend you.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Mr. Jones, I will not affect to miſunderſtand you; but if you have any regard for me, let me make the beſt of my way into the houſe—I wiſh I may be able to ſupport myſelf thither.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: I muſt firſt entreat your forgiveneſs of that, which love hath forc'd from me intirely againſt my will.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: You have my forgiveneſs, Mr. Jones. Fortune, not Sophia, is your enemy.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: And muſt I, cruel powers! reſign
This idol of my heart?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Alas! 'tis fate's decree, not mine;
We muſt forever part.
Farewel.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: Not yet— holding her.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I muſt away;
This freedom gives offence.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: O frown not!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: 'Tis a crime to ſtay,
When duty calls me hence.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Oh! how it tears my bleeding heart,
To think we muſt forever part!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: Yet, lovelieſt virgin, e'er you go,
Permit me to declare
To what exceſs I love.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: No, no:
Such tender tale forbear.
Adieu!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: Adieu!

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: How I repine
At fate's ſevere decree!
If India's utmoſt wealth were mine,
I'd give it all for thee.

div.trailer: The END of the FIRST ACT.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: DEAR Nightingale, you ſhould have conſider'd her want of fortune ſooner. On promiſe of marriage, you have won her to elope from a tender mother. You have made uſe of every effort to ſeduce her, and becauſe you cannot ſucceed, you want to ſhuffle her off. The girl is abſolutely ruined; for ſhould ſhe even return home immediately, it would be impoſſible to convince the world of her innocence.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: That's true! But 'tis the very devil to marry a woman without any fortune!

div.head: AIR.
div.l: 'Till luxury came into play,
And ſwell'd the expences of life,
Even dowerleſs beauty could ſway
Each youth in the choice of a wife.
But now ſuch a chargeable train
Of wants has the conjugal ſtate,
That women ſhould only be ta'en
Like money not current—by weight.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Well, ìf you don't marry her, Mrs. Miller will aſſuredly die of a broken heart; and I wiſh poor Nancy may not make her exit by more haſty means; ſo you will not only have the reputation of ruining the daughter, but the glory of killing the mother.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Upon my word, Tom, thou wouldſt have made a moſt admirable parſon!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Jack, I know you have not a bad heart, ſo prithee don't trifle on ſo ſerious a buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Well, if thou'lt accompany me to Upton, I'll marry her to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: With the greateſt pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: I'll to the poor girl, and comfort her: ſhe has ſcarce had a dry eye ſince morning—but pray in what ſituation are your affairs?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: My affairs are deſperate indeed! I had foſter'd ſome diſtant hopes of the lovely Sophia; but I muſt renounce her: the peace of a worthy family requires it—ſhe never can be mine, and my only relief muſt be to forget her—to ſhake off the ſlavery of an enfeebling paſſion, I will embrace the nobleſt of all paſſions, the love of my country, and enter a volunteer in its ſervice.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Sound, ſound aloud Britannia's name!
Her great and glorious deeds proclaim
To every foreign land:
Fame, ſing her conqueſts on the main;
All her brave ſons will join the ſtrain,
And ſwell the choral band.

div.head: SCENE, A Chamber.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: So, becauſe ſhe's expounding the Gazette, as Jones calls it, to my cuz Supple, I muſt be obliged to wait the lord knows how long? Tell her—Oh! here ſhe comes!—Get thee gone. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Mr. Supple, I'll be with you again, as ſoon as poſſible.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. WESTERN, with a Gazette in her Hand.
div.p: Things look ſo well in the North, that I was never in a better humour—Brother, I am now at your ſervice for a few minutes—your pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: I have open'd the matter to Allworthy, who is now in the dining-room, acquainting his nephew with it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Exceſſively well! You have acted like a wiſe and prudent father.—Brother, the Gazette brings good news. Things look very well in the North, and here's a pretty good article from Vienna. [reads.] The grand duke of Tuſcany was elected king of the Romans on the thirteenth, and—

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: But, dear ſiſter, let's mind our own affairs, and leave thoſe of the grand duke to ſome other time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Then prithee make haſte, for we have yet above a column and a half to go thro'—what doſt ſay, brother? I'm as impatient to be gone, as a vigilant general is to ſteal a march of the enemy—come, diſpatch, diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: As Blifil is in the houſe, ſuppoſe he and Sophy ſhould have a meeting immediately?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: That requires ſome conſideration— [looking on the Gazette] why—a—yes—no—certainly—by no means.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Yes—no—certainly—by no means!—The devil's in the woman to be ſure! It's confounded hard that you won't give a body a direct anſwer—nay, what ſignifies my talking?—You can't hear a ſyllable, while you've have that damn'd Gazette in your hand, unleſs I ſpeak as loud as a thunder-clap. Speaking very loud.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Brother!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: I aſk if they may'nt as well have a meeting immediately?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Who have a meeting?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Zounds! Sophy and Blifil.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Bleſs me! How you ſwear!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Swear! You'ld make a parſon ſwear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Well, let them have a meeting to open their amorous conferences. Reads.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: But ſhould'nt I acquaint Sophy with it before hand?—Nay, now you're at it again!—I muſt have recourſe to other means I find. Snatches the Gazette.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Brother, you are abſolutely a perfect Croat—but things look ſo well in the North, that I cannot be angry with you.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: I ſay ſhould'nt I—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: I'll not hear a word; not one word I aſſure you. I will by no means vouchſafe you a parley, till you make reſtitution of that literary acquiſition, which you have ſo piratically ſnatched from me.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: There it is for you—ſhouldn't Sophy be acquainted before hand?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Acquainted with what?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: With what? Why that ſhe and Blifil are to have a meeting. Loud.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: I proteſt, brother, you are enough to frighten one—but pray what were you aſking me?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: If Sophy ſhould not be acquainted with the intended meeting between her and Blifil?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Oh! by all means, brother! Pray go and inform her of it. You are the fitteſt perſon in the univerſe to be employ'd in ſuch an embaſſy—but poor Mr. Supple will be as anxious for my return, as a harraſs'd army, after a long campaign, is to go into winter-quarters— [reads] Letters from the Ottoman Porte bring advice that the infidels are forming an army of obſervation— Exit.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: The duce Ottoman Porte thee! I'm as tir'd as a dog of her damn'd nonſenſical politics—but here comes Sophy!

div.p: Well, Sophy, I've reſolv'd to marry thee to Blifil—what a plague doſt thou ſigh for?—Come, come, none of theſe maideniſh airs—your mother, I remember, whimper'd and whin'd at our marriage, but it was all over in eight and forty hours—cheer up, cheer up, child—I'll go and bring thy lover. Exit.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: How terrible is my ſituation! I can never marry this man—ſhall I then turn rebel againſt a father's authority, and violate one of the ſtrongeſt obligations that nature has impoſed on us? I ſhudder at the thought!

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Duty is nature's ſtrongeſt law;
A tie, that all ſhould have in view;
A debt of gratitude, love, awe,
To every tender parent due.
By heaven 'tis ſtamp'd upon our frames;
In poliſh'd minds it ſhines the moſt:
The wretch that duty's bond diſclaims,
Muſt be to every virtue loſt.

div.stage: Sits down in a muſing poſture.
div.p: And yet methinks duty cannot demand the ſacrifice of my own happineſs! Surely neither heaven nor nature require me, in obedience to a parent, to marry a man, with whom I muſt be for ever miſerable. Riſes.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: There ſhe is! To her, to her, coo her—that's it, you jolly dog—follow her, boy—run in, run in—that's it, Honeys—dead, dead, dead—don't ſtand ſhill I, ſhall I, but puſh matters home. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Miſs Weſtern, your moſt obedient humble ſervant—Mr. Weſtern, madam, has been telling me of the honour intended me, and it is hardly in the power of words to expreſs my joy on ſuch a happy occaſion.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Fathers, Mr. Blifil, are frequently too haſty in the diſpoſal of their children; and often involve them in real miſery, by endeavouring to promote their imaginary happineſs.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: I hope Mr. Weſtern is not in that claſs of parents: I am ſo much a friend to his daughter, that I ſhould be extremely ſorry he ſhould do any thing to occaſion her diſquiet.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Then, Mr. Blifil, the only way to ſhew your friendſhip, will be to decline your pretenſions; for ſuch is my preſent ſituation, that I cannot give you the leaſt encouragement.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: But, madam, may I be allow'd to aſk your reaſons?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: It is needleſs: I think I have already explain'd my ſelf ſufficiently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p:
Leave me ſo abruptly? Then it is pretty evident ſhe does not like me—no matter: As ſhe will be the key to the two eſtates, ſhe is ſtill an object worthy my purſuit—by marrying her, I ſhall not only ſucceed to the fortunes of both families, but compaſs a moſt deſirable point, the expulſion of Jones—the marriage muſt be hurried on as
faſt as poſſible: I begin to have ſome ugly fears about Dowling! It is very lucky that he is now in London—I muſt conceal Sophia's coldneſs, and tell her father ſhe has given me a moſt favourable reception, as that will be the only means to haſten the match—here he comes!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: My daughter, gone!—Well, how did ſhe receive you?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Beyond my hopes! Oh! ſhe's the moſt charming creature!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Tol lol de rol. Sings and capers about.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: So affable, ſo obliging!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Tol lol de rol.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: So eaſy! So winning in her deportment!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Tol lol de rol.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: So engaging in her manner! and ſo very favourable to my hopes!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: hugging and kiſſing him My dear boy, I ſhall be happier than either of you—run to your uncle, and bleſs him with the news— Exit Blifil.

div.p: HONOUR croſſes the Stage.
Honour, tell Sophy I want her.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Yes ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.l: How happy a father am I!
How bleſt the condition I'm in!
My heart is ſo light, that for joy
I could almoſt jump out of my ſkin.
Search England around and around,
Search all nations under the ſky,
And in 'em there will not be found
A father ſo happy as I,

div.p:
My dear Sophy, I'm the happieſt dog in the world! Chuſe what cloaths thou wilt, what jewels thou wilt; eat what thou wilt, drink what thou wilt, do what thou wilt; for
I have no other uſe for money, but to make thee happy— my dear, dear Sophy! thou'rt my only joy upon earth.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: And can my dear papa be ſo good, as to place all his joy in my happineſs?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Yes, burn me if I don't! Kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Then pray do not make me the moſt miſerable creature upon earth. Kneels.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: How? What? Staring wildly.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Alas! ſir, I cannot poſſibly marry Mr. Blifil.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Not marry Blifil?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: No indeed, ſir, I cannot—and will the beſt of fathers break my heart?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Pho! pho! pho! all ſtuff and nonſenſe!—break your heart indeed! As if marriage could break any woman's heart?—No, no; women's hearts are not ſo eaſily broken: I know that by experience; I could never break your mother's.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: A marriage with Mr. Blifil is even worſe than death.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: You ſhall have him; you ſhall by my ſoul! This is my fix'd reſolution, and ſo conſider on't. She catches hold of the ſhirt of his coat.

div.head: AIR.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: O do not look ſo wild!
Have pity on a child!
Such indignation my poor heart will break.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.l: Wretch! I will not hear you;
Hence! I cannot bear you:
In ſuch cauſe how dare you Speak?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Words of ſuch angry ſtrain
Rend my ſad heart in twain:
Can a fond father's reſolve be to kill?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.l: I ſhall ſwear and bluſter,
I'm in ſuch a fluſter.
Ceaſe this whining racket,
Or, I tell you roundly,
I ſhall thraſh your jacket Soundly
For thwarting my will.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Will nothing move you?
Think now I love you,
And with ſoft pity attend my ſad moan.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.l: 'Tis in vain to ſnivel.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Hear me—

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.l: Fly a thouſand mile hence.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: O hear me!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.l: Diſobedient devil!
Silence!
Go, go: get thee gone.

div.stage: He breaks from her; ſhe falls on the ground.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Dear ſir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: I have not breath to tell thee, Tom—that undutiful huſſy hath put me in ſuch a paſſion, that I could fight with my own ſhadow—prithee take her in thy arms, and ſet her in a chair.—I have been telling her my reſolution of marrying her to Blifil, and—

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: [ſtarting] Blifil!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Ay Blifil: what a pox didſt thou ſtart at?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: N—nothing, ſir; nothing at all—Mr. Blifil, ſir—to be ſure, ſir, is—a very un—equal—I mean unexceptionable match—confuſion! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Tom, you anſwer very queerly! What's the matter? Ar'n't you well?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Never worſe in my life, ſir. I've ſo violent a pain in my head, that I would thank any body for blowing out my brains this inſtant.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Blowing out one's brains is a ready way to be ſure to get quit of the head-ach—but, as I was telling thee, Tom, tho' I have reſolv'd to marry her to Blifil, the diſobedient young huſſy won't agree to the match.—You undutiful jade, I've a good mind to—but I won't put my ſelf in a paſſion; for paſſion is like—is like—is like dram-drinking; it ſets a man all in a blaze, all in a blaze, all in a blaze— [walks about fanning himſelf with his hat.] No, I'm reſolv'd I won't be in the leaſt paſſion imaginable—talk to her, Jones; I know ſhe has an opinion of thee—talk her into her duty—d'ye hear, Tom?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: If it is your pleaſure, ſir, I'll do it with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Wilt thou?—Give me thy hand—I'll leave thee with her, and I heartily wiſh thou mayſt prevail on her to do, as thou wouldſt have her.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: And ſo do I moſt ſincerely

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Give me thy hand again—thou'rt the beſt friend I have in the world—my dear Tom, leave nothing undone to gain thy point.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Nothing in my power, I aſſure you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Thank thee kindly: thou'rt a prince of a man—but may I be hang'd, drawn, and quarter'd, if I don't turn her out of doors, unleſs ſhe have him! May I be gibbetted if I don't! Exit.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Mr. Jones, for heaven's ſake how came you here? Leave me inſtantly I entreat you.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Do not impoſe on me ſo harſh a command—Turn not thus inhumanly from me—O ſpeak to me, Sophia! comfort my bleeding heart.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Alas! Mr. Jones, what comfort have I to beſtow? You know my father's intentions.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: But, at the ſame time, I know your compliance with them cannot be compelled.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Your beauteous looks inſpire my mind
With paſſion of the pureſt kind:
No ſelfiſh views my boſom ſway,
But all is love without allay.
Of ſuch a darling gem poſſeſs'd,
My lot would be ſupremely bleſt;
Poſſeſſion would increaſe my joy,
For charms like yours can never cloy.
With every charm, with every grace
Hath nature deck'd that form, and face;
At your creation heaven deſign'd
To ſhow a goddeſs to mankind.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Where's this raſcal, this Jones? I'll have his heart's blood!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: O heavens! My father! Faints in Jones's arms.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p:
Ha! my daughter fainting! Here, ſiſter! Honour!
Jenny! Help! Water! Water! Richard! Thomas! William! Water! Water! Water! Runs firſt to one door, then to another, then to Sophia.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. WESTERN, SUPPLE, HONOUR, and ſeveral Servants.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Stand off! leave her to me: I have ſome Aſſa foetida in my ſmelling-bottle—this will bring her to herſelf— [rubs her temples.] Brother, you will never leave off theſe boiſterous ways: you're enough to frighten half the ſex into fits—you won't ſtrive to get the better of that natural rage and brutality, notwithſtanding all the pains I take to lecture, and poliſh you into a civiliz'd being—Oh! ſhe revives!—Honour, help me to lead her off. Exeunt Mrs. Weſtern, Sophia, Honour, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Now I'll be reveng'd on the raſcal— [Supple holds him] cuz, let me go, for I will have ſatisfaction—off with thy cloaths, if thou'rt a man—off with thy cloaths I ſay, and I'll lick thee, as thou was't never lick'd in thy days— A damn'd beggarly baſtard! To come here a-poaching after my daughter!—Let me come at the dog; let me come at him I ſay: I can bear it no longer!

div.head: AIR Sir Roger de Coverly.
div.l: I'll humble my gentleman's pride, ſir:
Hands off—let me go I intreat you,
I long to be currying his hide, ſir—
To mummy, you dog, I could beat you!
My fingers now itch to be at you,
But cuz holds me faſter and faſter,
Or ſoon I would teach you, odd rat you!
To meddle with meat for your maſter.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Sir, this uſage is hardly to be born; but no abuſe, however virulent, can provoke me to retaliate on the father of Sophia. Exit.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: You raſcal, I'll fight you for fifty guineas, if you dare: nay I'll do't for pure love.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Here comes Mr. Allworthy!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Dear ſir, what is the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: You've brought up your by-blow, if he be yours, to a fine purpoſe. My daughter has fallen in love with him over head and ears, that's all—It's well for him that cuz would not let me get at him, or I'd have trimm'd him, I'd have ſpoil'd his catterwawling.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: But pray, ſir.—

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Yes, if ſhe will have him, the cloaths on her back ſhall be all her portion: I'd ſooner give my eſtate to the devil than to her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I am extremely ſorry that I conſented to his ſtaying with you, during the ſporting ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Pfha! Pox o'your ſorrow! It will do me abundance of good truly, when I have loſt my only child, that was all the joy, hope, and comfort of my age— (weeps) but ſhe ſhall beg, and ſtarve, and rot in the ſtreets for me. Not a farthing, no not a braſs farthing, ſhall ſhe have of mine—the raſcal was always a dab at finding a hare, but I little thought what puſs he was looking after—if I ſhould loſe my poor girl, it will break my heart; for I love her more than all the dogs, and horſes in the world. Weeps.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: This affair hath really amaz'd me!

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: And me too, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Pray, neighbour, when did you find it out?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Siſter told me juſt now.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: But did you never diſcover any ſymptoms of love between them?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: What the plague d'ye think I'm a conjurer?—No, no, no; you may be ſure they took care to keep the matter from me—I have indeed, now and then, ſeen him caſt a ſheep's eye at her, but that you know young fellows will do, without being in love: but, as I hope to be ſav'd, I never ſaw him kiſs her but once; and that was at my bidding, to puniſh her for bluſhing, when I told her, by way of banter, Jones was ſo handſome a fellow, that I was afraid ſhe would be falling in love with him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A wiſe puniſhment indeed! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: But I muſt away and look after the wench, for fear ſhe give me the flip.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Well, what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p:
Do? Warn the raſcal to keep away from this
houſe; for if I catch him here, curſe me if I am not the death of him! Exit.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: I had beſt follow, to prevent miſchief. Exit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: This youngſter's ingratitude touches me nearly—I cannot eaſily pardon his deſign on Miſs Weſtern—Blifil!

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Dear ſir, you ſeem diſturb'd.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Diſturb'd? Yes, I am diſturb'd, and diſtreſs'd to the laſt degree upon your account—I am ſorry to inform you that Miſs Weſtern is in love with Jones.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: In love with Jones?—Confuſion!—However, I'm but rightly ſerv'd—it is no wonder the man ſhould rival me, who has attempted to make me a beggar.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To make you a beggar? Explain yourſelf—What has he done?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: No matter, ſir—let it reſt.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Your reſerve will diſpleaſe me. I deſire to know the affair.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: I beg to be excus'd—to tell it at this time would have the appearance of malice.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Nephew, I inſiſt upon knowing it.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: An uncle's command muſt be obey'd—during your late ſickneſs—but pray excuſe me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I will admit of no excuſe—proceed.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: When you were given over by the phyſicians, he made a bold attempt to inherit your whole eſtate.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To inherit my whole eſtate? By what means?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: By ſuch as will hardly ſeem credible—he tampered with farmer Flail and his wife, to witneſs a will under your ſignature; offering them five thouſand pounds, and promiſing to marry their daughter.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Dear ſir, if you've the leaſt doubt, let the farmer be inſtantly ſent for.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Nephew, I know you're incapable of telling me a lie, therefore I want no farther proof.—A villain! I'll make him an example. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p:
The farmer is prepar'd: 'twas lucky that I plann'd the buſineſs with him this afternoon—The promiſe of a thouſand pounds, and the renewal of his leaſe, have ſecur'd
him—if I can but accompliſh the removal of Jones from my uncle, I ſhall be very eaſy about Sophia; ſhe may diſpoſe of her hand to whom ſhe pleaſes. Exit.

div.head: SCENE, A Chamber; a Table, on which are a Globe, ſeveral Maps, Pamphlets, and News-papers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Here is the map, couſin; now I'll ſhow you Franckfort—Ay, here is Franckfort! It muſt be a very large city, for the geographer has laid it down, in this ſmall map, full as big as a horſe-bean—well, I ſhould have lik'd to ſee the new emperor make his public entry into Franckfort. The proceſſion muſt be prodigiouſly ſuperb and magnificent!

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: No doubt on't—the election of the grand duke muſt be a very favourable circumſtance to the queen of Hungary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Oh! the moſt auſpicious event in the world! He will certainly put all the belligerent powers, now in hoſtility with his royal conſort, under the ban of the empire, if not actually declare war with them—yes, yes, as you obſerve, the queen's affairs will receive great benefit from the ſtrength of the emperor.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: I hope you will now indulge me with an audience on our own affairs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Then make it your audience of leave, for it is really too late to think of engaging in an offenſive and defenſive alliance for life.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Madam, it is never too late to be happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: But, couſin, will your hereditary dominions be able to furniſh adequate ſupplies for a combin'd army? The junction of our forces, tho' we ſhould have no infantry, muſt inevitably cauſe a great effuſion of money; and your revenues are not of the largeſt.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: If they fall ſhort, I preſume my dear ally will have no objection to furniſh her quota, as her finances are in ſo flouriſhing a ſtate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p:
You might perhaps be intitled to a ſubſidy from me as an ally. I don't mean as a Britiſh ally; for the allies of this iſland, inſtead of contributing to the expences
of a war, are often well paid for doing nothing—except defending their own territories—but do you really think we could live happily together?

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Certainly: with the moſt cordial affection; not with the faſhionable indifference, I might call it averſion, of modern couples.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Each noble of yore was ſo fond of his wife,
That marriage was held the chief bleſſing in life:
Each lady ſo loving, ſo chearful, and gay,
That all her delight was to pleaſe and obey.
But modern fine ladies and lords are above
So vulgar a paſſion, as conjugal love:
Such quarrels and partings have happen'd of late,
As if their chief paſſion were conjugal hate.

sp.p: Madam, I have ſuch a plan for ſpending the winter!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: A plan! Pray let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Laſt week you were wiſhing for a new tranſlation of your favourite Puffendorf. I will undertake it, and my amiable auxiliary ſhall enrich the work with her learned notes and annotations.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: This gives me as much joy, as the news of a complete victory over the French!—But—but—I ſay ſuppoſe you ſhould let me have the credit of the tranſlation?—Only oblige me in that, and I may ſurrender at diſcretion—come, you muſt, couſin: you poſitively muſt.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: I will if you'll give me one kiſs by way of earneſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: I think it quite ſufficient, if I ſuffer you to take one— there's my cheek; I never give more than the cheek; lips ſhould only be given to a huſband.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: In which ſenſe you ought now to regard me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: No, no, couſin; not till you've ratified the definitive treaty, and ſworn to it at the altar.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Pſha! I don't like ſuch cold kiſſes. Catches her in his arms and kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Good heaven! yonder is my niece! I'm in the utmoſt conſternation—pray, Mr. Supple, retreat with all poſſible precipitation— [Exit Supple.] I hope ſhe has not reconnoitred us! If ſhe has been lying in ambuſh to watch our motions, I am in a fine dilemma.

div.p: Well, niece, are you yet reconcil'd to the intended match?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Madam, it is impoſſible to be reconcil'd to the match, while I diſlike the man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Diſlike the man? If I were not fifty times a greater philoſopher than Plato, and five hundred times more placid than Socrates himſelf, you would poſitively put me in a rage—did ever any body hear ſo ridiculous an objection?—The liking of huſbands is now-a-days as much out of faſhion, as real patriotiſm.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: But, madam, where one's inclinations—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Inclinations! Inclinations quotha! I am abſolutely aſtoniſh'd at your aſſurance! One of your years talk of inclinations!—a girl! a child! a baby! an infant! a ſuckling!—Inclinations! Inclinations! Walks about in great ſtate.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Dear madam, I alone am concern'd, and my happineſs is at ſtake, wherefore—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: You alone concern'd? So far from it, madam, that you are not concern'd at all—do you conceive, miſtreſs, when a daughter of France is married into Spain, the princeſs alone is conſider'd in the match? No: the family alliance is the ſole object of conſideration; the princeſs is only thrown into the ſcale as a mere make-weight—'Tis the very ſame with great houſes, ſuch as ours. Walks about in great ſtate.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Madam, I ſhould be ſorry to do any thing to diſoblige my family; but as for Mr. Blifil, no force on earth ſhall compel me to marry him.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: The match, howe'er commodious,
Muſt meet my utmoſt ſcorn:
His paſſion would be odious,
Were he to empire born.
Such hate my ſoul poſſeſſes,
Each hardſhip I'd ſuſtain,
E'er liſten to th' addreſſes
Of ſuch deteſted ſwain.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt have him, as ſure as ever thou waſt born.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Why, ſir, will you dare to interfere, when I have undertaken to manage her?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: I'll manage her myſelf for the future.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: You manage her? Ha! ha! ha! She will be moſt gloriouſly manag'd indeed!—Such a boor as you talk of managing a young lady?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Boor? I'm no more a boor than yourſelf, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall endure your inſolence and brutality no longer—this is the laſt night I will ſleep in your houſe, I aſſure you

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: A good riddance!—Blood! it's enough to make my daughter undervalue my ſenſe, when ſhe hears you every hour calling me a fool.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: It is impoſſible that any one ſhould undervalue ſuch a blockhead.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Blockhead, madam? I've more ſenſe than you and your whole generation put together, tho' you're always preaching up your ſkill in politics, and great knowledge of the world—would any body but you have put me upon a wrong ſcent, about my daughter's being in love with Blifil? There was politics! there was knowledge of the world!—Ah! you old fool you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Tell James to get my coach— [Calls at the door.] An ill-bred provoking blockhead! I'll not ſtay another minute in his houſe.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Pray, my dear aunt—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Not another minute, I aſſure you, child.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: My coach!—I'll begone; and from this very hour
Ends all my alliance with ſuch a rude boor.
My ſex, my political knowledge deſpiſe?
By heaven! I could tear out the Hottentot's eyes—
An illiterate clown! give his tongue ſuch a looſe!
For the future I never ſet foot in your houſe—
Adieu, my dear child— this is uſage ſo trying,
In ſpite of my pride it will ſet me—a crying.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Loo! loo! loo! loo! loo!—Ay, let her go and be hang'd—I'm certainly the moſt unfortunate dog in the world! It is always my fate to be whipt in by the humours of ſome damn'd jade or other. —But curſe my jacket, if I will be run down in this manner by any of them!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Dear ſir, entreat my aunt to ſtay.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Stay? What to indict me for a plot, and have me hang'd, that the government may get my eſtate?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: My aunt, ſir, is ſo far from injuring you, that ſhe hath left you her whole fortune.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Ay, but ſhe's ſuch an odd-temper'd devil, I ſhall never be ſure of what ſhe has, till ſhe's at her laſt gaſp.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Then pray, ſir, entreat her to ſtay: a little ſubmiſſion will ſatisfy her.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: So, I muſt aſk pardon for your fault? You've loſt the hare, and I muſt draw every way to find her?—Well, for this once I'll take your advice, for fear of the worſt.—A damn'd old hag!—But I muſt humour her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: O lud, ma'am! poor Mr. Jones! poor Mr. Jones!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Is turn'd adrift by Mr. Allworthy, for making love to you. Poor creature! how he begg'd and pray'd to take his laſt farewel of you; but Mr. Allworthy would not allow it—the door ſtood a little a-jar, and I heard all that paſs'd.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me, Honour!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: When I found they were parting, I ran down the back-ſtairs, and met Mr. Jones in the hall. He look'd me full in the face, but was not able to ſpeak a word; preſs'd my hand, kiſs'd it, ſigh'd, beat his breaſt, burſt into tears, and then march'd off for the ale-houſe, where Black George, the game-keeper, is going to carry his cloaths to—I'm ſure my poor heart was ready to bre—bre—break, to ſee him in ſuch a pi—pi—piteous taking. Weeps.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: And have I been the cauſe of his ruin?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
Nay, ma'am, there's ſomething beſides you in the caſe. Mr. Allworthy charg'd him with a deſign of forging a will; which he ſolemnly denied, and even offer'd to
face his accuſers: But Mr. Allworthy would not give up his author.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Forge a will? Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ay, ma'am, full as impoſſible, as for me to fly over the moon.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Here; take my purſe—theſe rings—this watch—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ma'am, my maſter may miſs the watch and rings, and you may want the money.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Then thou ſhalt ſupply me—away! find Black George, and carry this to Mr. Jones—go, go, go. [Exit Honour.] Yes, I muſt loſe him for ever! What a pity it is, that the caſual difference of our ſituation ſhould make us both unhappy!

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Such beauty, manlineſs, and air
His form and face adorn,
Not half ſo lovely, half ſo fair
Appears the bluſhing morn:
His grace, his dignity, his eaſe
My fond affections ſtole;
He was by fate deſign'd to pleaſe,
And captivate the ſoul.

div.head: SCENE, A Dinning-Room.
div.stage: Enter ALLWORTHY, WESTERN, Mrs. WESTERN, and BLIFIL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: As Mr. Allworthy is guarantee for your future behaviour, I will grant you a peace; but take care how you renew hoſtilities with me.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Dear ſiſter, I'll never offend you again, while breath's in my body.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Away then, and bring your daughter to her ſwain. [Exit Weſtern.] Mr. Allworthy, our plan of operations muſt be concerted for a ſurprize, not a ſtorm.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Madam, I am utterly againſt all violent meaſures.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: But I hope, ſir, you will indulge me with another interview?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I have no objection to that: uſe every fair method to gain her, but no compulſion.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Here ſhe is, Blifil—come, let's leave 'em together—She's more complying than I expected.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ſhe will capitulate at laſt. The ſtrongeſt citadel muſt yield to a vigorous ſiege. Exeunt Allworthy, Weſtern, and Mrs. Weſtern.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Miſs Weſtern, I am once more ſo happy, as to be with you alone; and now let me hope for a more favourable hearing.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Mr. Blifil, ſhall I be ingenuous with you?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, madam.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Then let me once more declare to you, it is impoſſible that I can be yours.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Why impoſſible, Miſs Sophy? Time perhaps—

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Don't flatter yourſelf; I ſhall never conſent, and it will be in vain to give yourſelf any further trouble about me.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: And is this your ſerious reſolution?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: It is: I therefore hope you will immediately deſiſt.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: If this be the caſe, I muſt apply to Mr. Weſtern, and your aunt.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Apply to whom you pleaſe, I never can ſuffer it.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Excuſe me, madam, if I don't take this anſwer from you—I ſhall acquaint Mr. Weſtern with what has paſs'd, and leave you to declare your ſentiments and reſolutions to him. Exit.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Inſufferable aſſurance!—Tho' I tremble at the thoughts of diſobeying a father, yet all his authority cannot compel me to marry this deteſted inſolent.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: O dear Ma'am! I'm frighten'd out of my wits!—My maſter has been ordering the ſteward to take horſe for a licence. He ſwore with a great oath, that you ſhould be married to Mr. Blifil to-morrow.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: To-morrow! (leans on Honour.] Support me—pray, dear Honour, give me thy advice—What wouldſt thou do in my caſe?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Do? Why any thing to be ſure before I would marry a man I could not abide.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: But what wouldſt thou do in my ſituation?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Go off directly to London, ma'am.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Fly from my father? No, no, no; I can never think of this deſperate remedy—good heaven! What will become of me?—I ſhall run diſtracted—let us to my chamber; perhaps we may hit on ſome expedient.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Only be rul'd by me, ma'am, and all will be well, I warant you.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: To be tied to a fellow one hates were a curſe,
A curſe I could never ſurvive;
Nay ſooner than take him for better, for worſe,
By Jove! I'd be buried alive.
Should pappy inſiſt on my wedding a man,
Whoſe ſight would occaſion the hip;
E'er into ſuch marriage he ſhould me trapan,
By Jingo! I'd give him the ſlip.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: And you thought I intended to leave you?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I confeſs I was not without my fears; but you have effectually remov'd them, by the aſſurance you have given me of our marriage to-morrow—I am now really happy!

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Bleſt with thee, my ſoul's dear treaſure,
Sweetly will each hour be paſs'd;
Every day will bring new pleaſure,
And be happier than the laſt.
With ſo lov'd a partner talking,
Time will quickly glide away:
With ſo dear a huſband walking,
Nature all her bloom diſplay.
Such a darling ſwain poſſeſſing,
All my ſorrows will be o'er;
Thou art fortune's utmoſt bleſſing,
Fortune cannot give me more.

sp.p: And ſhall we ſet off for Upton to-night?

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: As ſoon as ever poor Jones hath finiſh'd his letter to Mr. Allworthy.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I pity the unfortunate gentleman, and ſhall always love him for thoſe noble principles, which you tell me he diſplayed in your late interview.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Yes, my dear Nancy, his generous advice hath greatly contributed to our happineſs. I muſt own that the fear of a father's reſentment operated on me very ſtrongly.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: How ſorry my mamma will be for this breach between Mr. Jones, and his benefactor!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: I've diſpatched my letter, and now am ready to attend you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And pray, ſir, how do you find yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Abundantly eaſier—I have taken my everlaſting leave of the moſt adorable Sophia.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Leave of Sophia! You have not ſeen her? Have you?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: No: I've eternally renounced her in my letter. I have given up love to glory and patriotiſm. My country is now my miſtreſs, whom I will ſerve with the moſt inviolable fidelity.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: My youthful boſom glory fires,
I feel its all-enlivening breath;
This arm Britannia's cauſe requires;
Then welcome fame, or welcome death.

sp.speaker: All three.
sp.l: Crown, propitious fortune, crown
The brave with conqueſt, and renown!

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.l: Ariſe, dread genius of this iſle!
This iſle, which foreign wonder draws;
With fame's firſt honours crown their toil,
Who bleed, or conquer in her cauſe.

sp.speaker: All three.
sp.l: Crown, propitious fortune, crown
The brave with conqueſt, and renown!

sp.speaker: All three.
sp.l: Bright beauty's tribute ſhall be paid
To the ſurviving ſons of fame;
And each fond matron, each fond maid,
With love reward her hero's flame.
Crown, propitious fortune, crown
The brave with conqueſt, love, renown!

div.trailer: The END of the SECOND ACT.

div.head: SCENE, An Inn at Upton.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: WITH a woman ſayſt thou? Can it be?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: As ſure as my name's Honour, ma'am. I got a full view of him, as the maid carried in the tea-kettle.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Then there is no truth in man—order the horſes: inſtead of flying to my couſin at London, I will return home.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: But, ma'am—

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Falſe, falſe man!—I'm aſham'd of this weakneſs—away!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Well, were it my caſe, I would mortify my gentleman; I would bounce into the room, and ſurprize them.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Thou haſt inſpired me with a thought—yes, he ſhall know I have been here— [writes with a pencil on a piece of paper] there's my name; pin it to the muff, and bribe the maid to convey it into the room. Bid her lay it where he cannot miſs ſeeing it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I ſhall, ma'am. Exit.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Baſe, inconſtant, and ingrateful man! How had inclination tempted me to deviate from duty!—but from this moment, I will abandon the thoughts of him, and his perfidious ſex for ever.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: To changeful man's deluſive arts
Let maids beware how they give way;
Nor yield too haſtily their hearts,
Leſt each with me repenting ſay,
"Deſerted by my ſaithleſs ſwain,
"Poor I, alas! muſt love in vain."

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Betty has carried it in—ſhe ſays there's a crack in the wainſcot, through which one may ſee them—Oh! here it is!—I'll have a peep—they ſit very lovingly together—Ah! the duce take you, for a falſe-hearted creature!—She ſits with her back this way: I wiſh ſhe would turn about, that one might ſee her face!—Take a peep, ma'am; do.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: No, no, no; I won't trouble myſelf about him.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: With what pleaſure he looks on her!—Now he reſts his elbow on the table, and ſeems grave—now he's all life and gaiety—Ah! you're a pretty gentleman!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: A baſe man! I bluſh at the recollection of my paſt folly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ha! he ſtarts! his eyes are fixed on the muff—He takes it up, and ſeems quite aſtoniſhed—Ay, ay, his conſcience begins to fly in his face!—he leaves the room!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: He is coming here then—lock the door—Good heaven! what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Do? E'en ſee him, ma'am.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: See him! No, no, no: I'll never ſee him more.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I vow he's talking to Betty—He comes this way—that's he! A knocking at the door.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: How ſhall I avoid him?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Get into this cloſet. Sophia goes into the cloſet.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Miſs Weſtern!—Madam!—Sophia!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Who's there? [very loud.]

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: 'Tis I, dear Honour—pray open the door, She unlocks the door.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Bleſs me, ſir! who thought of ſeeing you here?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Dear Honour, where's your lady?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: At home, I ſuppoſe: I've left her ſervice. Very coldly.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: No, no; the maid tells me ſhe is in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Well, if ſhe is in the houſe, ſhe won't ſee you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Not ſee me? how have I offended her?—I muſt ſpeak to her—I muſt indeed, Honour.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: She's in that cloſet— [very loud] I tell you, ſir, you may as well be gone, for ſhe'll have nothing to ſay to you.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: She's in this cloſet; I hear her ſtir—'tis ſhe!—ſhe comes! Sophia comes from the cloſet.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: Tell me, lovely charmer, why
You thus a fond adorer fly?
You cannot ſurely harbour ſtrife
'Gainſt him, that loves you more than life!
No longer, then no longer ſhun
The ſwain, by love and thee undone.
Why thus a fond adorer fly?
Lovely charmer, tell me why?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I beg, ſir, you will leave me inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: But why, my dear angel, ſo cruel a requeſt?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: No matter: I know too much, ever to think of you more.

sp.speaker: Jon.
