sp.p: If to love and adore you more than ever man did woman; if to prefer your happineſs to my own; if to dread your diſpleaſure more than death itſelf be criminal, I plead guilty: but—

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Be at no trouble to juſtify yourſelf, ſir—What! not paſs one day after you had left me, without devoting yourſelf to another!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: To another?—To whom?—May heaven—

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Hold, Sir! do not add perjury to inconſtancy.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I ſaw you with her, Mr. Jones, I'll take my Bible-oath on't.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: With a madam, if I muſt ſpeak plain Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Jon
sp.p: Me? when? where?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Yes, you; juſt this minute; in next room, ſir.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: That young lady—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Lady! A very fine lady! Of the right ſort I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Miſs Weſtern, if there be any faith in man —

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: No excuſes; they are quite needleſs.—I am almoſt diſtracted. Aſide, and walking about.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: [Following her] Sophia!—my moſt adorable Sophia!—Nay, this is ſo perverſe—Miſs Weſtern!—my dear angel!—Honour!—Mrs. Honour!—Then there's but one way to convince them. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What does he mean? He ſeems to face us down; but ſeeing's believing all the world over.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: How does my dear ſchool-fellow?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Miſs Miller! [they ſalute] What brings you here?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: A run-away ſcheme—I ſuppoſe ſomewhat like your own, my dear. Mr. Nightingale has prevailed on me to take a matrimonial trip.—We were in your neighbourhood yeſterday, and came hither laſt night, accompanied by Mr. Jones—The rector, it ſeems, is on a viſit at a friend's, about five miles hence; and Mr. Nightingale went to him, near three hours ago, to procure a licence; leaving me in the care of this gentleman till his return.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: I hope the matter is now explain'd, madam?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: And ſo I find it has been jealous of me? Has it?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: My dear Nancy, how could you be ſo raſh?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Ah! my dear, what is it that a woman won't do for the man ſhe loves?

div.head: AIR.
div.l: To lure me from mammy the ſwain did employ,
On every occaſion, the ſtrongeſt perſuaſion:
At length I conſented, and told the dear boy,
That thro' the world with him I'd wander with joy.
Tho' prudes and old maids, by deſpair ever teiz'd,
My conduct ſhould handle with malice and ſcandal,
So vaſt an affection my boſom has ſeiz'd,
That thro' the world with him I'd wander well-pleas'd.

sp.p: As I live there's Mr. Nightingale, and a gentleman!—Excuſe me, Miſs Sophy; I muſt attend my lord and maſter. Exit ſinging, And thro' the world with him.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: So! Now miſs is gone, the beſt thing I can do is to leave them together: leaſtwiſe I ſhould like to be ſerv'd ſo myſelf. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: O Sophia! did you but know the torments I have ſuffer'd, ſince we parted, you would not thus have added to my affliction, by ſuppoſing me capable of inconſtancy.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I confeſs I was too haſty; but appearances partly juſtified my ſuſpicions—And yet, alas! why ſhould I intereſt myſelf in your conduct?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Why not, my angel? Give me but the leaſt hope, and I will wait till time, and ſome favourable event ſhall reconcile your father.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Alas! Mr. Jones, you know I am not miſtreſs of myſelf.—Yet I will confeſs, that did not duty forbid, even ruin with you would be preferable to the moſt affluent fortune with another.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Ruin! Oh! Sophia, can I be the villain to ruin thee? No; by heavens! no: I will give you up; yes, I will give you up for ever; tho' it muſt render me completely miſerable.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Where can we run? Where can we fly,
To hide us from your father's eye?
This place in troth won't hold us both —
Was ever ſuch a luckleſs elf?
What ſhall we do?—Here's room for you—
In, in—I'll ſcamper for't myſelf.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Stay, Honour—My father! heaven and earth! is he come?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He, Mr. Allworthy, Supple, and that odious pragmatical Blifil are juſt lighted.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Ruin'd paſt redemption!

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Away to miſs Miller, and leave me to ſtand the brunt. Exeunt Sophia and Honour.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Shew me her chamber—I'll unkennel her—I'll have her, if ſhe be above ground.

div.stage: Enter ALLWORTHY, WESTERN, SUPPLE, and BLIFIL.
div.p: Illo ho! illo ho! we've got the dog-fox; I'll warrant madam is not far off— [ſeizes Jones] Where's Sophy, you raſcal?— [Jones ſhakes him off.] Sirrah, you've ſtole my daughter, and I'll have you hang'd.—I have not been in the commiſſion of the peace ſo long, not to know it is a hanging matter to ſteal an heireſs.—You ſhall ſwing for't, you dog; you ſhall be tuck'd up; you ſhall dangle. I expect to be prickt for high-ſheriff, and I'll ſee you executed.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Sir, I can aſſure you I was not in the leaſt privy to miſs Weſtern's flight.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Don't ſay ſo, Mr. Jones: this proves you guilty. Taking up the muff.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: It is miſs Sophy's; I've ſeen her wear it.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: My daughter's? So it is I'll be ſworn!—Bear witneſs, gentlemen; the goods are found in his cuſtody; in ſuo cuſtodium—this will do his buſineſs—tol lol de rol—he ſhall be hang'd for it, an it coſt me ten thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: It is in vain, Mr. Jones, to perſiſt in this falſhood. If you did not decoy the young lady away, how comes ſhe to be here with you?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Ay, pray how comes ſhe to be here with you?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Right! how comes ſhe to be here with you?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: By mere accident I aſſure you, gentlemen. Miſs Miller, who is in the next room, will convince you of it.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Pho! pho! pho! All a pack of damn'd lies!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: However, neighbour, if he did not decoy her away, he will, in my eye, appear a good deal leſs criminal.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: But where's Sophy, you villain?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: In the next room with Miſs Miller. [Exeunt Allworthy, Weſtern, Supple, and Bliſil. My dear Sophy! I fear the violence of her father's temper will be too much for her.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: My dear Tom, I've got the licence.—Pray do you know my couſin Dowling, the attorney?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Very well: what of him?

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: I overtook him about a mile from hence; and happening to ſpeak of Mr. Allworthy's diſpleaſure, he ſaid he muſt communicate to him an affair, which would reinſtate you in his favour.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Where is Miss Weſtern, madam?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: In the next room with her papa and the gentlemen—Poor creature! ſhe will have a ſad time on't.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Excuſe me: I muſt know the iſſue of this buſineſs. Exit.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Nancy, let me have a diſh of coffee, and then we'll to church.—I am now truly happy! So ſincere is my love, that I would not exchange thee for a diadem.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: When I'm in nuptial union join'd
With my enchanting fair,
What raptures will poſſeſs my mind!
What tranſports ſhall I ſhare!
From ſuch a ſweet engaging wife
New joys muſt hourly ſpring,
I would not change ſo bleſt a life
To be the greateſt king.

div.head: SCENE, A large Room. A tankard on the table.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Your obſtinacy is not to be endur'd—What does the girl ſnivel and cry for?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Alas! my dear father, I can't help it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ah! it's an old croſs-grain'd patch! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: What can I do more to make you happy? You know I love you ſo well, that I would ſee all the world hang'd, before I would even have your little finger hurt.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: The world is very much oblig'd to you truly! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p:
And yet all this won't do.—But I muſt ſecure you, till I have breakfaſted.—In—in to that room.—In with
you both— [Exeunt Sophia and Honour.] There!— [locks the door] I have her as ſecure now, as a fox in a bag.—Whew! [whiſtles] Here, houſe!—Whew!—

div.p: Landlady, I want ſomething for breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Coffee or tea, your honour's worſhip?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Pox on ſuch rot-gut ſtuff! Some ham, cold buttock of beef, veniſon paſty, or any thing on the ſubſtantial order.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: We've nothing cold; the ſoldier fellows have eat up all.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Ah! the devil take them! A ſwarm of red-coat locuſts! They'll eat up the whole nation by and by.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Would your honour's worſhip chuſe ſome new-laid eggs and bacon?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Nothing better: 'tis a breakfaſt for an emperor! Get them ready as faſt as poſſible—And hark you—ſend me a pipe; I've tobacco of my own.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Yes, an't pleaſe your honour's worſhip. Exit.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: This is excellent beer i'faith! I'm one of your true Engliſhmen; I hate all ſlipſlops.

div.head: AIR. Roaſt Beef.

lg.l: When good queen Elizabeth, hiſtory's boaſt,
From Spaniards and Frenchmen defended our coaſt,
The noblemen feaſted on bak'd, boil'd, and roaſt.
O the roaſt beef of Old England!
And O the Engliſh roaſt beef!

div.stage: Enter landlady, with pipes, &c. and exit.

lg.l: The ladies delighted in good hearty chear,
Their breakfaſt in common was beef and ſtrong beer.
O the ſtrong beer of Old England!
And O the Engliſh ſtrong beer!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Sure no one ever had ſo intolerable a journey!—I'm fatigued to death I—I ſhan't be able to riſe out of my chair theſe three hours—I'm jolted to pieces—Well, where's my niece?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Lock'd up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Lock'd up! I thought you would be taking ſuch head-ſtrong meaſures!—Why will you pretend to meddle with matters, ſo infinitely beyond your knowledge?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Zounds ànd blood! did ever any body hear the like! To be fallen upon in this manner, when I expected you would commend me for what I've done!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Commend you? Your operations are diametrically oppoſite to my free principles, and totally inconſiſtent with Magna Charta—Let my niece be ſet at liberty this inſtant, and given up to my management—Will you agree to this ſtipulation?—I expect a categorical anſwer—Either cede her intirely to me, or take her wholly to your own ſurpriſing diſcretion; and then I here, before Mr. Supple, evacuate the garriſon, and renounce all family-compact with you for ever.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Mr. Weſtern, let me be a mediator.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: There's the key: ſhe may take it up if ſhe will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: No, ſir; I inſiſt on the formality of its being deliver'd.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: There then—I wiſh old ſcratch had her! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: If your daughter had always liv'd with me, you would have had no occaſion for locks, bolts, nor bars.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Zounds and the devil! What would you have me do?—You're enough to make me raving mad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: There now! Look you there! Juſt according to his old cuſtom! Flying out upon every occaſion, right or wrong—Abſolutely, brother, there is no ſpeaking to you! If I were not a woman of the meekeſt diſpoſition upon earth, I could not poſſibly live under the ſame roof with you—I will appeal to Mr. Supple, whom every body allows to be a man of great ſenſe, if I have ſaid even one individual thing, to put any human being, except ſuch an iraſcible animal as yourſelf, into the leaſt paſſion imaginable.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Let me beg you, dear madam, not to irritate him any further.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p:
Irritate him! You are ten times a greater blockhead than himſelf. It is my misfortune to be
hemm'd round by ſuch fools and dunces!—Mercy on all affairs under the guidance and direction of you men!—you are ſuch a parcel of purblind creatures!—The head of one woman is worth fifty thouſand of yours. Unlocks the door, and exit.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: A fractious, croſs-grain'd, contradictious, ſelf-opiniated, Preſbyterian, Oliverian hag! when ſhe takes to a thing, one can no more turn her from it, than a young beagle can turn an old hare:—I was a damn'd fool ever for thinking of her eſtate; but as I've been a ſlave ſo long, it would be a pity to loſe it at laſt, for want of holding out.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Couſin, I highly commend your prudence.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. WESTERN, SOPHIA, and HONOUR.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: The world is come to a fine paſs indeed, if we muſt be lock'd up when every whimſical huſband, or father takes in into his ſelf-ſufficient noddle to confine us!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Very true, ma'am! locking, and bolting, and barring won't do for an Engliſhwoman.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: The ſwarthy Italian the privilege claims
To lock up, in family-durance, the dames
Of every condition, of every degree:
But here we defy ſuch tyrannical knaves;
The females of England will never be ſlaves:
Fate, cuſtom, and charter, to favour the fair,
'Gainſt locking, and bolting, and barring declare,
And wiſely ordain that our ſex ſhall be free.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Well, you remember the ſtipulation?

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I'll neither meddle nor make. The girl can never be in better hands. My cuz here will do me the juſtice to own, that I've been praiſing you up to the ſkies, and ſaying you was the beſt-temper'deſt woman in the world, and fit to have the care of a princeſs-royal—have not I, cuz? Winks at Supple.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Yes indeed, and a great deal more, ſir. I never heard you ſpeak more handſomely of Mrs. Weſtern in my life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p:
Brother, I'm ſatisfied—you are naturally too
raſh and precipitate; but when you give yourſelf time to reflect, I don't know a man more reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p:
I am indeed a little paſſionate, but, like all true Engliſhmen, I ſcorn to bear malice—But come, cuz, let's go to breakfaſt; I've ordered ſome eggs and bacon—B'ye, my dear ſiſter— [kiſſes her] we'll never have another quarrel, as long as we live—I wiſh ſhe were once dead with all my heart! [aſide]
Exeunt Weſtern and Supple.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Eggs and bacon for breakfaſt! What a Hottentot!—who would ſay he is any thing a-kin to me! [looks in a pocket glaſs.] Bleſs me! what a fright am I! This journey has made me look ten years older.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: In my opinion you never look'd better, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: O fie, child! no, no, Sophy: faces will grow worſe for wear—but for all that, I've had my conqueſts, and a coronet among them; but he was remarkably ugly, and very poor—Sophy, I was never ſo handſome as you, and yet I had a great deal of you formerly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ma'am, Mr. Blifil deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Well, child, what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Pray, my dear aunt, don't ſuffer him to come in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Well, well, he ſhan't—I'll go to him—yes, yes, I have had my conqueſts. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Ma'am, you ſeem to have got the old lady into a very good humour; but a little flattery always does it, for ſhe loves it as well as a girl of nineteen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Miſs Weſtern, if you're at leiſure, I could wiſh to have a little converſation with you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: That's as much as to ſay, "March, Honour." Exit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'm extremely ſorry, madam, for the uneaſineſs I have occaſioned; but it was not my fault:

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I hope, ſir, you are not offended at my behaviour to your nephew?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
No apology, dear madam. Such a diſcovery hath
been made, that I muſt always bluſh at the reflexion of his being my nephew—yet I could ſtill wiſh to have ſo accompliſhed a young lady in my family; wherefore I beg leave to make you a tender of—

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: I hope Mr. Allworthy's good ſenſe will prevent him from making any offers of that kind?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Madam, I am juſtly reprehenſible for not explaining myſelf ſooner: the tender I mean is not on my own, but my nephew's account.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Your nephew's? I thought you had ſaid—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I don't mean that wretch Blifil, but one whom I am pretty ſure you will like—the very man, whom I am confident you would wiſh.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Heaven and earth! Mr. Jones!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: It is, it is— [embraces her, and weeps.] I have uſed him very hardly, in ſo haſtily and cruelly diſmiſſing him. I feel more on the occaſion thàn I am able to expreſs.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: I aſk pardon, ſir: I thought you were alone. Going.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Stay—hark you, ſir—ſee that you find me the letter, which your mother ſent me on her death-bed.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Letter, ſir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, letter— your mother ſent me one by Mr. Dowling. Did not he deliver it to you?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Villain, how can you have the effrontery to deny it?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Sir, I can deny it very ſafely—This muſt be ſome colluſion between Jones and Dowling. It is of a piece with my rival's behaviour, relative to the forged will.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: That too I look upon as an infamous falſhood—You have offered Dowling a large ſum, to conceal the circumſtance of your brother's birth: he will ſwear it.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Sir, if Mr. Dowling has a mind to ſwear away my life, I can't help it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Provoking villain! See here, to your utter confuſion, a duplicate of the letter, ſign'd by your mother, and atteſted by the clergyman, that attended her in her laſt illneſs.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Then I'm undone! Dowling never mentioned the duplicate— [aſide] Alas! my dear uncle, I confeſs my crime, and— Kneeling.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I want no reply—ſee my face no more—go, and the reproaches of a guilty mind, the bittereſt of all puniſhments, attend you—Yet ſtay—I am ſorry that I ſhould thus upbraid you—To inſult a perſon in affliction is a ſpecies of revenge, which baſe and illiberal minds can only entertain—I ſhall order my ſteward to pay you a thouſand pounds, which is the laſt favour you muſt ever expect from an injured uncle—retire— [exit Blifil.] I aſk pardon for this behaviour; but his villainous ſuppreſſion of the letter ſo affected me, that I could not command my temper.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Rage is ſo ungovernable a paſſion, and you had ſo juſt an occaſion for it, that an apology was unneceſſary—but pray, dear ſir, forgive him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Forgive him! impoſſible!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Sweet mercy is the lovelieſt flower,
That Heaven e'er planted in the mind;
The queen of virtues, whoſe ſoft power
Can even to godhead raiſe mankind.
Let patriots, kings, and heroes boaſt
A name, that will in hiſtory live;
Yet he reſembles Heaven the moſt,
Whoſe godlike boſom can forgive.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Neighbour, this raſcal Jones has not left the inn yet. I wiſh you'ld grant me a warrant, and I'll have him committed for a vagrant.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I think the young man has ſuffered enough already.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Suffered enough! why he deſerves hanging.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'm of a contrary opinion; and know he has been greatly injured: I am therefore reſolved to make him amends, by making him my heir.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Your heir! What! make Tom your heir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: It is my firm reſolution.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p:
Curſe me! if I'm not glad on't, for he's a jolly dog. I always thought he wanted nothing but a fortune, to be the
clevereſt fellow in all England—but pray how comes this about?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He is a very near relation of mine.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Oh, ho! I ſmoke you! So then you've had a colt's tooth in your head when you were young, as well as other folks, old ſly-boots?—But it's only what I thought; for I always ſuppos'd him to be your ſon, by your bringing him up like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He is not my ſon, but the ſon of my ſiſter, who, two years before her marriage with Capt. Blifil, was privately married to Mr. Sumner.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Sumner! What! the handſome clergyman, that you brought up? Parſon Gillyflower, as I us'd to call him?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Gad, I have often thought that Tom had a great look of him—Well, if you're in the mind, we'll clap up a match between Jones and Sophy?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Nothing can be more agreeable to me.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: And to thee too, my little gipſy, I'll anſwer for't—you ſee ſhe's all ſcarlet at the very mention of it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: She's a moſt beautiful creature indeed!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: So much the better for Tom, for egad he ſhall have the towſling of her.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Dear ma'am, for goodneſs' ſake come away: poor miſs Miller is in a fit. Exeunt Sophia and Honour.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Give her a hearty tweak by the noſe: the beſt thing in the world—I ſaw a recruiting ſerjeant recover the ſqueaking landlady at Gloſter by it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What can be the matter? Oh! here's an explanation of the affair.

div.stage: Enter Old NIGHTINGALE, dragging in his ſon; SUPPLE interpoſing.

sp.speaker: Old Night.
sp.p: Come along, you dog: I won't let you ſtay another minute—you're a fine gentleman indeed, to run away with a huſſy that has not a penny!—You raſcal, I've a good mind to horſewhip you, as long as I can ſtand over you.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: I beg, ſir, you will be pacified.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Lord! I wonder how any man can put himſelf in ſuch a paſſion!

sp.speaker: Old Night.
sp.p: If I had not come juſt in the nick—for I have not been here ſince I went to live in Berkſhire—If I had'nt ſeen cuz Dowling, by the mereſt chance in the world, it had been all over as clean as a whiſtle—The provoking 'ſcape-grace has the impudence to tell me he'll marry her, though I ſhould diſinherit him—Yes, ſirrah, I will diſinherit you; cuz Dowling ſhall make my will immediately; and as ſoon as I have executed it, I'll hang myſelf for fear I ſhould change my mind—I'll be reveng'd on you.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Miſs Miller, ſir, is more to me than all the wealth in the world.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Come, don't be ſo angry, Mr. Nightingale. I'll engage to make miſs Miller a fortune of ten thouſand pounds, if you will conſent to the match.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Excuſe me, ſir; I can't accept a fortune from you.

sp.speaker: Old Night.
sp.p: Why not, Jack? If he has a mind to give it, what buſineſs haſt thou to oppoſe it?

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: Sir, my conſcience won't ſuffer me to take it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I will ſatisfy your ſcruples, young gentleman. A chancery-ſuit, which I have carried on for Mrs. Miller againſt the ſon of her guardian, was the other day determined in her favour; and ſhe is now worth upwards of fifteen thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Old Night.
sp.p: And pray what childer has ſhe?

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: None but my dear Nancy.

sp.speaker: Old Night.
sp.p: Jack, give me thy fiſt—thou art not altogether ſo great a puppy as I thought thee—get ready for church, and I'll ſtand father.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: I'll go and bleſs my Nancy with the news.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: The poor creature is better.—Mr. Nightingale, how could you be ſo boiſterous?—I am come to negotiate a general pacification. You ſurely cannot deny it to your old flame? Thirty years ago you would have acceded to any demand from me.

sp.speaker: Old Night.
sp.p: Madam, all is made up, and I'll go and ſee my daughter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Will Mr. Allworthy be ſo kind as to lend me his mediation?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: In what can I ſerve you, Mr. Supple?

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: In bringing Mr. Weſtern to conſent to my marriage with this lady.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: How! What a plague is this! Màrry at fifty-three! Why, ſiſter, did not you promiſe me, when my wife died, if I would live ſingle, that you would never marry?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: You a politician and depend on the promiſes of a woman in love-affairs? You might as well depend on the promiſes of the French.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Your family, Mr. Weſtern, will be no loſer by the match. Sophy is my neareſt relation, and ſhall inherit all I have.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: As this is the caſe, if ſiſter's inclinable—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Brother, I muſt own I eſteem Mr. Supple, as he is a man of ſenſe, and a great admirer of female underſtandings. He has already made ſome amorous advances; and ſhould he beſiege me in form, after I have held out a few months, I may poſſibly be inclined to liſten to terms of capitulation.

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: A few months? dear madam, that will be too long a blockade. If you're reſolv'd to defend the garriſon to the laſt extremity, I find I muſt begin the attack by ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Ay, ay, cuz; begin with ſtorming, and I warrant you'll carry her.—Come, ſiſter, you may as well conſent, and we'll have both marriages together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Well, brother, if this beſieger will agree to certain articles—

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: Dear madam, I will grant you a carte blanche.

div.stage: Enter OLD NIGHTINGALE, NIGHTINGALE, SOPHIA, and NANCY.

sp.speaker: Old Night.
sp.p: I thought my daughter before a mere painted doll; but, now I've ſeen her again, ſhe looks like an angel.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: That's becauſe ſhe'll be a fifteen thouſand pounder. Lord! how fond of money are ſome people! [Aſide.] But what has become of my friend Jones all this while?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: He is gone to wait upon his brother with compliments of condolance.—This is an unexpected revolution indeed!

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: My old friend Tom, I am glad to ſee thee with all my heart.—I muſt have a buſs of thee, dear dog.—All paſt muſt be forgotten.—Chriſtians muſt forget and forgive one another.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: I hope, ſir, I ſhall never forget the many obligations I am under to Mr. Weſtern.—My brother, Sir, is extremely ſorry for his offence, and humbly begs leave to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Tell him I don't know him.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, let me intercede in his behalf.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: You are both too good: for your ſakes I will keep him above want.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Weſ.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let him retire with a penſion.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: And now, dear ſir, if I could hope you would countenance my addreſſes to this young lady—

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: It's all done: the match is agreed on.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Then I'm the happieſt man in the world.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.p: You'll except me, Mr. Jones?

sp.speaker: Sup.
sp.p: And me too? this lady and I will convince you, that matrimonial happineſs is not ſolely confin'd to yourſelves.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.p: Well ſaid, cuz.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: My happineſs, I am perſuaded, will hardly be inferior to any of yours. He, who rewards merit, and promotes the bliſs of others, muſt always feel the greateſt happineſs himſelf.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: Each deſire is now complete;
Here all female graces meet;
Each fond wiſh at laſt is crown'd;
Bliſs and happineſs abound.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Queens, enjoy your pomp and ſtate;
Be, as pride can make you, great;
At your lot I'll ne'er repine;
State be yours, but love be mine.

sp.speaker: Night.
sp.l: Love's a ſpark of heavenly flame,
Lent to warm the human frame:

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.l: Love ſincere can never cloy;
Love's the ſource of every joy.

sp.speaker: Old Night.
sp.l: Dear Miſs, I aſk your pardon there,
With you I can't agree;
For drinking claims the greateſt ſhare
In man's felicity.
Then drink about, ſee it out, jolly jolly topers;
Drink about, ſee it out, jolly jolly topers:
Love's milkſop joys can ne'er compare
With Bacchanalian glee.

sp.speaker: Weſ.
sp.l: If I muſt chant a ſtave at all,
I'll ſing in Nighty's tune:
I hate Italian ſhake and ſquall,
Tho' they're in ſuch renown:
I love a ſong, ſhort or long, jolly jolly ſongſters;
I love a ſong, ſhort or long, jolly jolly ſongſters;
Which goes to a fal, lal, lal, lal, lal,
Or a down, down, hey derry down.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Long may love and marriage reign!
Sound, to marriage ſound the ſtrain!
The ſupremeſt bliſs in life
Is the kind, the virtuous wife.
Love's a ſpark of heavenly flame,
Lent to warm the human frame:
Love ſincere can never cloy;
Love's the ſource of every joy.
Long may love and marriage reign!
Sound, to marriage ſound the ſtrain!
The ſupremeſt bliſs in life
Is the kind, the virtuous wife.
